definitions.definition: to get well again after being ill, hurt, etc.

examples.text: He's still recovering from his operation.
She spent many weeks in hospital **recovering from her injuries**.
He has **fully recovered** from the shoulder surgery.
She remains in serious condition, but is expected to recover.
The victim is **recovering well** at home.
Mrs Burton was last night recovering from her injuries in hospital.
She had hardly recovered from the birth of her last baby.
Yates is struggling to recover form a serious knee injury.
Your baby is recovering well.
Mother and baby are recovering well.

definitions.definition: to return to a normal state after an unpleasant or unusual experience or a period of difficulty

examples.text: It can take many years to recover from the death of a loved one.
The economy is at last beginning to recover.

definitions.definition: to get back the same amount of money that you have spent or that is owed to you

examples.text: He is unlikely to ever recover his legal costs.
Creditors have a right to recover their debts.
Some investors tried to recover their losses by making further high risk investments.

definitions.definition: to get back or find something that was lost, stolen or missing

examples.text: The police eventually recovered the stolen paintings.
Six bodies were recovered from the wreckage.

definitions.definition: to win back a position, level, status, etc. that has been lost

examples.text: The team recovered its lead in the second half.

definitions.definition: to get back the use of your senses, control of your emotions, etc.

examples.text: It took her a few minutes to **recover consciousness**.
to recover your sight
She seemed upset but quickly recovered herself.

wordOrigin: Middle English (originally with reference to health): from Anglo-Norman French recoverer, from Latin recuperare ‘get again’.
